description:
Halteromyces radiatus is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Basidiomycota. It is a member of the order Agaricales, which includes a diverse group of mushroom-forming fungi.

Halteromyces radiatus is known for its unique morphological features. The fruiting body, or mushroom, typically has a cap that is circular in shape and can reach up to 10 centimeters in diameter. The cap surface is dry and has a distinctive radial pattern, with grooves or ridges extending from the center to the edge. The gills, or spore-bearing structures, are attached to the underside of the cap and are typically white or pale in color.

The species is found in various parts of the world, including Europe and North America, and is often associated with decaying wood or soil rich in organic matter. Halteromyces radiatus plays an important role in the decomposition of organic materials, contributing to the cycling of nutrients in forest ecosystems.

While the species is not known to be edible or have any significant medicinal properties, it is of interest to mycologists and researchers studying the diversity and ecology of fungi.
